input.speaker: user
input.text: what makes the different shapes of the moon

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The different shapes of the Moon, also known as lunar phases, are determined by the amount of sunlight that is illuminating the portion of the Moon visible from Earth. This changes as the Moon orbits the Earth and the relative positions of the Moon, Earth, and Sun shift. When the Sun, Earth, and Moon are aligned, with the Sun and Moon on opposite sides of the Earth, we see a full moon. When the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun, we see a new moon. The crescent and gibbous shapes occur during the intervals between these principal phases, when only a portion of the Moon's surface is illuminated. The specific shape at any given time depends on the Moon's position in its orbit. When a sphere is illuminated on one hemisphere and viewed from a different angle , the portion of the illuminated area that is visible will have a two - dimensional shape defined by the intersection of an ellipse and circle ( where the major axis of the ellipse coincides with a diameter of the circle ) . If the half - ellipse is convex with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be gibbous ( bulging outwards ) whereas if the half - ellipse is concave with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be a crescent .

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the distance between the moon and earth?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The average distance from the Moon to the Earth is about 238,856 miles or 384,402 kilometers. But this distance varies throughout the Moon's orbit, ranging from about 221,500 miles or 385,000 kilometers at its closest, to about 252,700 miles or 406,700 kilometers at its farthest resulting in a differential range of 50,200 kilometers or 31,200 miles. Lunar distance (astronomy) Astronomers O'Keefe and Anderson calculated the lunar distance by observing 4 occultations from 9 locations in 1952 . They calculated a mean distance of 7008384407600000000 ♠ 384 407. 6 ± 4.7 km , however the value was refined by in 1962 by Irene Fischer , who incorporated updated geodetic data to produce a value of 7008384403700000000 ♠ 384 403. 7 ± 2 km .

input.speaker: user
input.text: How can I protect my personal information from identity theft

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
Here are some tips to protect your personal information from identity theft:
1. Do not respond to or click on any links within unsolicited emails or pop-up boxes. They can put your personal information in jeopardy.
2. Be cautious when using your debit card online. Consider using a credit card instead as they typically provide added protection against fraudulent charges.
3. Only download mobile applications from official app stores and check other users’ reviews, as well as the app’s privacy policies, before downloading.
4. Use a variety of strong and unique passwords for your online activities. Avoid using the same password for all your accounts.
5. Keep your financial documents and records in a secure place. Shred sensitive materials before disposing of them.
6. Secure your wireless network with a strong password and turn on Wireless Network Encryption if available.
7. Lock your computer when you are using it in a public or shared space.
8. Regularly update anti-virus protection software on your computer and keep your computer system and browser up to date.
9. Double-check mailings and always make sure that documents are not stuck together and that the recipient’s information is correct before sending any Personally Identifiable Information.
10. Avoid sending any sensitive information via email. If you must use email, consider purchasing encryption software.
11. Use social media responsibly and monitor your privacy settings.
12. Consider purchasing and using a reputable Virtual Private Network or VPN software to use while online using public networks.
For parents, it's important to start the conversation about online safety with your children, establish rules, monitor their playtime, and teach them about cell phone safety.

input.text: why was the eastern roman empire called the byzantine empire

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Modern historians refer to the Byzantine Empire as such to distinguish it from ancient Rome. This name comes from Byzantium, the original name of Constantinople, the capital city of the empire. The citizens of the empire continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire or Romania and to themselves as "Romans."

input.speaker: user
input.text: What was its religion?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
During the reign of Constantine in the Byzantine Empire, Christianity was not declared the exclusive state religion, but it received special favor from the emperor, who granted it generous privileges. Constantine also established the principle that emperors could not unilaterally decide matters of religious doctrine, and instead, they should convene general ecclesiastical councils for that purpose. His summoning of the Synod of Arles and the First Council of Nicaea demonstrated his commitment to the unity of the Church and asserted his authority as its leader.The ascendancy of Christianity was briefly challenged when Emperor Julian came to power in 361 and sought to revive polytheism throughout the empire. He was later known as "Julian the Apostate" by the Church. However, Julian's efforts were reversed when he died in battle in 363.
The foundation of the Byzantine Empire was based on the belief that it was a reflection of the Kingdom of Heaven on Earth. Just as God ruled in Heaven, the Emperor, created in His image, was expected to govern on Earth and uphold His commandments. The empire aspired to be universal and aimed to encompass all the peoples of the Earth. Ideally, all people would be members of the one true Christian Church, the Orthodox Church.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was reorganized?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Constantine I reorganized the Roman Empire in the early 4th century, around 324-337 AD. This reorganization included establishing Constantinople as the new capital and legalizing Christianity. Constantine's changes marked a significant shift that set the stage for the development of the Byzantine Empire as a distinct entity from the classical Roman Empire. Constantine moved the seat of the Empire to Constantinople, which he founded as a second Rome on the site of Byzantium, a city strategically located on the trade routes between Europe and Asia and between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Constantine significantly changed the Empire's military, monetary, civil, and religious institutions.

input.text: There are different theories about why Rome fell. Emperors, concerned for their personal safety and public peace, resorted to corrupting the military discipline, ultimately leading to the military government's weakening and dissolution. This weakening was further exacerbated by the partial institutions of Constantine, ultimately leading to the Roman world being overrun by Barbarians. Historians are still analyzing the reasons for the loss of political control over a vast territory and the survival of the Eastern Roman Empire. Alexander Demandt listed 210 theories on why Rome fell, and new ideas continue to emerge. Gibbon's classic formulation of reasons for the Fall sparked ongoing controversy about the role of Christianity but also emphasized other causes of internal decline and external attacks on the Empire.

Roman historians used the AUC system to measure the number of years between events rather than to indicate the date of a year. The Fasti Capitolini used an epoch of 752 BC, while modern historians have adopted the epoch of Varro, 753 BC. The AUC dating system was sometimes added in Renaissance manuscripts, giving the false impression that the Romans numbered their years. Censorinus stated that, in his time, the AUC year began with the Parilia, celebrated on 21 April, which was seen as the actual anniversary of the foundation of Rome. According to Roman myth, Rome was founded by Romulus, the first to dedicate spoils taken from an enemy ruler to the Temple of Jupiter Feretrius. input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
There are some potential advantages and disadvantages of Immutable Object Storage:  
Advantages:  
1. Data Integrity and Long-term Data Retention: Immutable Object Storage preserves electronic records and maintains data integrity. It ensures that data is stored in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many), no-erasable and non-rewritable manner, which can be beneficial for industries like Financial, Healthcare, and Media content archives where data integrity is crucial. 
 2. Compliance: Immutable Object Storage can help organizations comply with certain regulations like SEC Rule 17a-4(f), FINRA Rule 4511(c), and CFTC Rule 1.31(c)-(d) that govern electronic records storage and retention. When using immutable Object Storage, it is the client's responsibility to check for and ensure whether any of the feature capabilities that are discussed can be used to satisfy and comply with the key rules around electronic records storage and retention governed by the above-mentioned regulations.
Disadvantages:  
1. Limited Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only. Users outside these regions may not be able to use this feature. 
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan, which could be a disadvantage for users looking for more affordable options.  
3. No High-speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy. This could potentially slow down the data transfer process.  
4. Irreversible: Once permanent retention is enabled, it can't be reversed. Objects uploaded that use a permanent retention period cannot be deleted. This means users need to be sure about their need to permanently store objects. 
5. Legal Holds: The retention policy is enforced until the end of a retention period and the removal of any legal holds. This could potentially cause issues if there are legal disputes or investigations. Please note that the actual advantages and disadvantages may vary depending on the specific use case and requirements.
To assist clients in making informed decisions, IBM engaged Cohasset Associates Inc. to conduct an independent assessment of IBM’s Immutable Object Storage.

input.text: The Great Wall of China was built using various materials over different periods. Originally, it was mainly constructed from rammed earth, stones, and wood. input.speaker: user
input.text: How long is the Wall?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The frontier walls built by different dynasties have multiple courses. Collectively, they stretch from Dandong in the east to Lop Lake in the west, from present - day Sino - Russian border in the north to Qinghai in the south. The walls built by the Ming dynasty measure 8,850 km. Faced with the threat of the Göktürks from the north, the Qi built up to 3,000 li about 1,600 kilometers. The Xuan - Da portion of the Great Wall totaled about 850 kilometers of wall, with some sections being doubled - up with two lines of wall, some tripled or even quadrupled. Chancellor Wanyan Xiang convinced the emperor to build an extensive systems of walls, which consisted of a 700 kilometers outer wall from Heilongjiang to Mongolia and a 1,000 kilometers network of inner walls, north and northeast of Beijing. Together, they formed a roughly elliptical web of fortifications 1,400 kilometers in length.

input.text: Who was the enemy?

input.text: Many scholars have operated under the belief that the Great Wall continually defended China 's border against the raids and invasions of the various nomadic groups of the Eurasian Steppe with an eye to expansion. The usefulness of the Great Wall as a defense line against northern nomads became questionable under the Qing dynasty, since China proper, Manchuria, and Mongolia were all under Qing control. So instead, the Great Wall became the means to limit Han Chinese movement into the steppes. input.text: what is the defense of marriage act 1996

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) is a United States federal law that defines and protects the institution of marriage. enacted in 1996. It was introduced by Georgia Representative Bob Barr and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma. The Act was intended by Congress to reflect and honor a collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality. It also defined marriage for federal purposes as the legal union of a man and a woman as husband and wife, and a spouse as a husband or wife of the opposite sex. Section 3 of DOMA defines marriage and spouse for federal purposes. Section 3 codified non-recognition of same - sex marriages for all federal purposes, including insurance benefits for government employees, social security survivors ' benefits, immigration, bankruptcy, and the filing of joint tax returns, as well as excluding same - sex spouses from the scope of laws protecting families of federal officers, laws evaluating financial aid eligibility, and federal ethics laws applicable to opposite - sex spouses.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How are weddings celebrated?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The typical wedding involves a couple proclaiming their commitment to one another in front of their close relatives and friends , often presided over by a religious figure such as a minister , priest , or rabbi , depending upon the faith of the couple . In traditional Christian ceremonies , the bride 's father will `` give away '' ( hand off ) the bride to the groom . Secular weddings are also common , often presided over by a judge , Justice of the Peace , or other municipal official . At a wedding reception , the father of the bride , in his role as host , regularly offers the first toast , thanking the guests for attending , offering tasteful remembrances of the bride 's childhood , and wishing the newlyweds a happy life together . The best man usually proposes a toast in the form of best wishes and congratulations to the newlyweds . A best man 's toast takes the form of a short speech ( 3 -- 5 minutes ) that combines a mixture of humor and sincerity . The actual `` toast '' is then delivered at the end of the speech and is a short phrase wishing the newlyweds a happy , healthy , loving life together . The maid of honor may follow suit , appropriately tailoring her comments to the bride . The groom may offer the final toast , thanking the bride 's parents for hosting the wedding , the wedding party for their participation , and finally dedicating the toast to the bridesmaids .

input.text: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Assuming the question is about the IBM Cloud® Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI),  version 6.15.0 includes the following changes over version 6.14.0. It introduces new commands image-obsolete and image-deprecate for image lifecycle management. It also adds support for image lifecycle management in image-create, image-update, and images commands and it fixes an issue with using the SSH key generated from UI in CLI.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Tell me more about the new commands

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The new commands introduced in version 6.15.0 of the IBM Cloud® Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI) are image-obsolete and image-deprecate. These commands support image lifecycle management, allowing users to manage the lifecycle of their custom images more effectively. The image-obsolete command can be used to mark an image as obsolete, indicating that it is no longer available to be used to provision an instance. The image-deprecate command can be used to mark an image as deprecated, discouraging its use before it becomes obsolete.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How do I use them?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: To use the new `image-obsolete` and `image-deprecate` commands, you need to specify the name or ID of the custom image with the `IMAGE` variable.  To mark an image as deprecated, use the following command:  ```  ibmcloud is image-deprecate IMAGE  ``` - To mark an image as obsolete, use the following command:  ```  ibmcloud is image-obsolete IMAGE  ``` These commands allow you to make an immediate status change. Alternatively, you can schedule these status changes for a future date and time by using the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--deprecate-at` or `--obsolete-at` options. Finally, please note that you can only make an immediate status change if a future status change is not scheduled. If you have a scheduled status change, you need to remove it first.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Can I use the scheduling functionality to schedule a status change to obsolete in a month and to deprecated in two months?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Yes, as I described previously, you can use the scheduling functionality to schedule a status change to obsolete and deprecated in the future using the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--obsolete-at` and `--deprecate-at` options. Note, if you define both the deprecate-at and obsolete-at dates, the obsolete-at date must be after the deprecate-at date. In addition, when scheduling the date and time, you can't use your current date and time but a month and two months in the future is acceptable.

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The different shapes of the Moon, also known as lunar phases, are determined by the amount of sunlight that is illuminating the portion of the Moon visible from Earth. This changes as the Moon orbits the Earth and the relative positions of the Moon, Earth, and Sun shift. When the Sun, Earth, and Moon are aligned, with the Sun and Moon on opposite sides of the Earth, we see a full moon. When the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun, we see a new moon. The crescent and gibbous shapes occur during the intervals between these principal phases, when only a portion of the Moon's surface is illuminated. The specific shape at any given time depends on the Moon's position in its orbit. When a sphere is illuminated on one hemisphere and viewed from a different angle , the portion of the illuminated area that is visible will have a two - dimensional shape defined by the intersection of an ellipse and circle ( where the major axis of the ellipse coincides with a diameter of the circle ) . If the half - ellipse is convex with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be gibbous ( bulging outwards ) whereas if the half - ellipse is concave with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be a crescent .

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the distance between the moon and earth?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The average distance from the Moon to the Earth is about 238,856 miles or 384,402 kilometers. But this distance varies throughout the Moon's orbit, ranging from about 221,500 miles or 385,000 kilometers at its closest, to about 252,700 miles or 406,700 kilometers at its farthest resulting in a differential range of 50,200 kilometers or 31,200 miles. Lunar distance (astronomy) Astronomers O'Keefe and Anderson calculated the lunar distance by observing 4 occultations from 9 locations in 1952 . They calculated a mean distance of 7008384407600000000 ♠ 384 407. 6 ± 4.7 km , however the value was refined by in 1962 by Irene Fischer , who incorporated updated geodetic data to produce a value of 7008384403700000000 ♠ 384 403. 7 ± 2 km .

input.speaker: user
input.text: How old is the moon?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Using the rate of recession to calculate the Moon's age suggest the Moon is approximately 1.5 billion years old while scientific consensus assumes an age of approximately 4 billion years.

Red Hat Virtualization and Red Hat OpenShift Virtualization are not the same. Red Hat Virtualization is a comprehensive platform for managing virtual machines and is based on KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) technology. It focuses on traditional virtualization needs, providing a robust environment for running and managing virtualized workloads.

On the other hand, Red Hat OpenShift Virtualization is an extension of the OpenShift platform, allowing users to run and manage virtual machines alongside containerized applications. It integrates virtualization into the OpenShift ecosystem, enabling a hybrid approach to application deployment.

In summary, while both solutions involve virtualization, they serve different purposes and are designed for different environments.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How can I protect my personal information from identity theft

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
Here are some tips to protect your personal information from identity theft:
1. Do not respond to or click on any links within unsolicited emails or pop-up boxes. They can put your personal information in jeopardy.
2. Be cautious when using your debit card online. Consider using a credit card instead as they typically provide added protection against fraudulent charges.
3. Only download mobile applications from official app stores and check other users’ reviews, as well as the app’s privacy policies, before downloading.
4. Use a variety of strong and unique passwords for your online activities. Avoid using the same password for all your accounts.
5. Keep your financial documents and records in a secure place. Shred sensitive materials before disposing of them.
6. Secure your wireless network with a strong password and turn on Wireless Network Encryption if available.
7. Lock your computer when you are using it in a public or shared space.
8. Regularly update anti-virus protection software on your computer and keep your computer system and browser up to date.
9. Double-check mailings and always make sure that documents are not stuck together and that the recipient’s information is correct before sending any Personally Identifiable Information.
10. Avoid sending any sensitive information via email. If you must use email, consider purchasing encryption software.
11. Use social media responsibly and monitor your privacy settings.
12. Consider purchasing and using a reputable Virtual Private Network or VPN software to use while online using public networks.
For parents, it's important to start the conversation about online safety with your children, establish rules, monitor their playtime, and teach them about cell phone safety.

input.speaker: user
input.text: why was the eastern roman empire called the byzantine empire

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Modern historians refer to the Byzantine Empire as such to distinguish it from ancient Rome. This name comes from Byzantium, the original name of Constantinople, the capital city of the empire. The citizens of the empire continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire or Romania and to themselves as "Romans."

input.speaker: user
input.text: What was its religion?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
During the reign of Constantine in the Byzantine Empire, Christianity was not declared the exclusive state religion, but it received special favor from the emperor, who granted it generous privileges. Constantine also established the principle that emperors could not unilaterally decide matters of religious doctrine, and instead, they should convene general ecclesiastical councils for that purpose. His summoning of the Synod of Arles and the First Council of Nicaea demonstrated his commitment to the unity of the Church and asserted his authority as its leader.The ascendancy of Christianity was briefly challenged when Emperor Julian came to power in 361 and sought to revive polytheism throughout the empire. He was later known as "Julian the Apostate" by the Church. However, Julian's efforts were reversed when he died in battle in 363.
The foundation of the Byzantine Empire was based on the belief that it was a reflection of the Kingdom of Heaven on Earth. Just as God ruled in Heaven, the Emperor, created in His image, was expected to govern on Earth and uphold His commandments. The empire aspired to be universal and aimed to encompass all the peoples of the Earth. Ideally, all people would be members of the one true Christian Church, the Orthodox Church.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was reorganized?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Constantine I reorganized the Roman Empire in the early 4th century, around 324-337 AD. This reorganization included establishing Constantinople as the new capital and legalizing Christianity. Constantine's changes marked a significant shift that set the stage for the development of the Byzantine Empire as a distinct entity from the classical Roman Empire. Constantine moved the seat of the Empire to Constantinople, which he founded as a second Rome on the site of Byzantium, a city strategically located on the trade routes between Europe and Asia and between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Constantine significantly changed the Empire's military, monetary, civil, and religious institutions.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Why it fall?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: There are different theories about why Rome fell. One theory suggests that the victorious legions, who acquired the vices of strangers and mercenaries during distant wars, first oppressed the republic's freedom and later violated the majesty of the purple. Emperors, concerned for their personal safety and public peace, resorted to corrupting the military discipline, ultimately leading to the military government's weakening and dissolution. This weakening was further exacerbated by the partial institutions of Constantine, ultimately leading to the Roman world being overrun by Barbarians. Historians are still analyzing the reasons for the loss of political control over a vast territory and the survival of the Eastern Roman Empire. Alexander Demandt listed 210 theories on why Rome fell, and new ideas continue to emerge. Gibbon's classic formulation of reasons for the Fall sparked ongoing controversy about the role of Christianity but also emphasized other causes of internal decline and external attacks on the Empire.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was it found?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The Romans did not consistently use a specific system for numbering the years from the founding of their city. Different historians had different dates for the founding. Roman historians used the AUC system to measure the number of years between events rather than to indicate the date of a year. The Fasti Capitolini used an epoch of 752 BC, while modern historians have adopted the epoch of Varro, 753 BC. The AUC dating system was sometimes added in Renaissance manuscripts, giving the false impression that the Romans numbered their years. Censorinus stated that, in his time, the AUC year began with the Parilia, celebrated on 21 April, which was seen as the actual anniversary of the foundation of Rome. According to Roman myth, Rome was founded by Romulus, the first to dedicate spoils taken from an enemy ruler to the Temple of Jupiter Feretrius. In subsequent wars, blood-stained armor and weaponry were gathered and placed in temples as a symbol of respect towards the enemies' deities and as a way to win their patronage.

When Charlemagne (known as Karl der Große in German) inherited the Frankish realm, he expanded it to cover all of Central and Western Europe, except for the southern tip of Italy and Iberia. input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the different types of dialog nodes?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: There are various types of dialog nodes. These include the Welcome node, which greets users when interacting with the assistant, and the Anything else node, which provides responses for unrecognized user input. You can also create custom nodes by adding a condition that triggers the assistant to process the node. It is possible to create an intent that can be recognized when a customer asks to speak to someone. After defining the intent, you can add a root-level dialog node that conditions the intent.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Whatar are intents?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Intents are the purposes or goals expressed in a customer's input, such as answering a question or processing a bill payment. By recognizing the intent in a customer's input, the Watson Assistant service can choose the appropriate dialog flow to respond. Intents added from a content catalog are distinguishable from other intents by their names. Each intent name is prefixed with the content catalog name.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How is it created?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
To create a dialogue, follow these steps:
1. Click the Dialog tab and then click Create dialog. When you open the dialog editor for the first time, the Welcome and Anything else nodes will be created for you.
2. To add more nodes, click the "More" icon on the Welcome node and select Add node below.
3. In the "If assistant recognizes" field, enter a condition that, when met, triggers your assistant to process the node. Typically, you want to add an intent as the condition.
4. Specify the condition and response for each node. The condition specifies the information that must be present in the user input for the node to be triggered, while the response is the utterance that your assistant uses to respond to the user.
5. Save your progress.
Remember, the dialogue matches intents (what users say) to responses (what the bot says back) and can ask for more details in a text response and create one or more child nodes to process the new input.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
There are some potential advantages and disadvantages of Immutable Object Storage:  
Advantages:  
1. Data Integrity and Long-term Data Retention: Immutable Object Storage preserves electronic records and maintains data integrity. It ensures that data is stored in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many), no-erasable and non-rewritable manner, which can be beneficial for industries like Financial, Healthcare, and Media content archives where data integrity is crucial. 
 2. Compliance: Immutable Object Storage can help organizations comply with certain regulations like SEC Rule 17a-4(f), FINRA Rule 4511(c), and CFTC Rule 1.31(c)-(d) that govern electronic records storage and retention. When using immutable Object Storage, it is the client's responsibility to check for and ensure whether any of the feature capabilities that are discussed can be used to satisfy and comply with the key rules around electronic records storage and retention governed by the above-mentioned regulations.
Disadvantages:  
1. Limited Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only. Users outside these regions may not be able to use this feature. 
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan, which could be a disadvantage for users looking for more affordable options.  
3. No High-speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy. This could potentially slow down the data transfer process.  
4. Irreversible: Once permanent retention is enabled, it can't be reversed. Objects uploaded that use a permanent retention period cannot be deleted. This means users need to be sure about their need to permanently store objects. 
5. Legal Holds: The retention policy is enforced until the end of a retention period and the removal of any legal holds. This could potentially cause issues if there are legal disputes or investigations. Please note that the actual advantages and disadvantages may vary depending on the specific use case and requirements.
To assist clients in making informed decisions, IBM engaged Cohasset Associates Inc. to conduct an independent assessment of IBM’s Immutable Object Storage.

1. Data Integrity and Long-term Data Retention: Immutable Object Storage preserves electronic records and maintains data integrity. It ensures that data is stored in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many), no-erasable and non-rewritable manner, which can be beneficial for industries like Financial, Healthcare, and Media content archives where data integrity is crucial. 
 2. Compliance: Immutable Object Storage can help organizations comply with certain regulations like SEC Rule 17a-4(f), FINRA Rule 4511(c), and CFTC Rule 1.31(c)-(d) that govern electronic records storage and retention. When using immutable Object Storage, it is the client's responsibility to check for and ensure whether any of the feature capabilities that are discussed can be used to satisfy and comply with the key rules around electronic records storage and retention governed by the above-mentioned regulations.
Disadvantages:  
1. Limited Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only. Users outside these regions may not be able to use this feature. 
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan, which could be a disadvantage for users looking for more affordable options.  
3. No High-speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy. This could potentially slow down the data transfer process.  
4. Irreversible: Once permanent retention is enabled, it can't be reversed. Objects uploaded that use a permanent retention period cannot be deleted. This means users need to be sure about their need to permanently store objects. 
5. Legal Holds: The retention policy is enforced until the end of a retention period and the removal of any legal holds. This could potentially cause issues if there are legal disputes or investigations. input.text: The frontier walls built by different dynasties have multiple courses. Collectively, they stretch from Dandong in the east to Lop Lake in the west, from present - day Sino - Russian border in the north to Qinghai in the south. The walls built by the Ming dynasty measure 8,850 km. Faced with the threat of the Göktürks from the north, the Qi built up to 3,000 li about 1,600 kilometers. The Xuan - Da portion of the Great Wall totaled about 850 kilometers of wall, with some sections being doubled - up with two lines of wall, some tripled or even quadrupled. Chancellor Wanyan Xiang convinced the emperor to build an extensive systems of walls, which consisted of a 700 kilometers outer wall from Heilongjiang to Mongolia and a 1,000 kilometers network of inner walls, north and northeast of Beijing. Together, they formed a roughly elliptical web of fortifications 1,400 kilometers in length.

input.text: Many scholars have operated under the belief that the Great Wall continually defended China 's border against the raids and invasions of the various nomadic groups of the Eurasian Steppe with an eye to expansion. Towards the end of the Ming, the Great Wall helped defend the empire against the Manchu invasions that began around 1600. The usefulness of the Great Wall as a defense line against northern nomads became questionable under the Qing dynasty, since China proper, Manchuria, and Mongolia were all under Qing control. So instead, the Great Wall became the means to limit Han Chinese movement into the steppes. Contrary to the building of the outer walls, which were built to stabilize the newly united China, the inner walls threatened the unity of the empire. In the north, the state of Wei and the Yiqu built walls to protect themselves from Qin aggression, but were still unable to stop Qin from eating into their territories. The settlement of the north continued up to Qin Shi Huang 's death in 210 BC.

Meng Tian introduced 30,000 settler families to colonize the newly conquered territories. When Meng Tian's settlements in the north were abandoned, the Xiongnu nomads moved back into the Ordos Loop as the Qin empire became consumed by widespread rebellion. Upon Qin Shi Huang's death in 210 BC, Meng Tian was ordered to commit suicide in a succession conspiracy.

input.text: The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) is a United States federal law that defines and protects the institution of marriage. enacted in 1996. It was introduced by Georgia Representative Bob Barr and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma. It also defined marriage for federal purposes as the legal union of a man and a woman as husband and wife, and a spouse as a husband or wife of the opposite sex. Section 3 of DOMA defines marriage and spouse for federal purposes. Section 3 codified non-recognition of same - sex marriages for all federal purposes, including insurance benefits for government employees, social security survivors ' benefits, immigration, bankruptcy, and the filing of joint tax returns, as well as excluding same - sex spouses from the scope of laws protecting families of federal officers, laws evaluating financial aid eligibility, and federal ethics laws applicable to opposite - sex spouses.

input.text: How are weddings celebrated?

Secular weddings are also common , often presided over by a judge , Justice of the Peace , or other municipal official . At a wedding reception , the father of the bride , in his role as host , regularly offers the first toast , thanking the guests for attending , offering tasteful remembrances of the bride 's childhood , and wishing the newlyweds a happy life together . The best man usually proposes a toast in the form of best wishes and congratulations to the newlyweds . A best man 's toast takes the form of a short speech ( 3 -- 5 minutes ) that combines a mixture of humor and sincerity . The actual `` toast '' is then delivered at the end of the speech and is a short phrase wishing the newlyweds a happy , healthy , loving life together . The maid of honor may follow suit , appropriately tailoring her comments to the bride . The groom may offer the final toast , thanking the bride 's parents for hosting the wedding , the wedding party for their participation , and finally dedicating the toast to the bridesmaids .

On the other hand, bad bots range from malicious to simply annoying; for instance, breaking into user accounts to steal data or buying concert tickets online to assist scalpers. This detection technique gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS and cannot identify specific individuals. Additional steps are taken to anonymize and phase out data for privacy.

input.text: How does CIS manage bots?

The detection mechanisms used by CIS produce their own scores, which are then combined to form a single score.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Assuming the question is about the IBM Cloud® Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI),  version 6.15.0 includes the following changes over version 6.14.0. It introduces new commands image-obsolete and image-deprecate for image lifecycle management. It also adds support for image lifecycle management in image-create, image-update, and images commands and it fixes an issue with using the SSH key generated from UI in CLI.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Tell me more about the new commands

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The new commands introduced in version 6.15.0 of the IBM Cloud® Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI) are image-obsolete and image-deprecate. These commands support image lifecycle management, allowing users to manage the lifecycle of their custom images more effectively. The image-obsolete command can be used to mark an image as obsolete, indicating that it is no longer available to be used to provision an instance. The image-deprecate command can be used to mark an image as deprecated, discouraging its use before it becomes obsolete.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How do I use them?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: To use the new `image-obsolete` and `image-deprecate` commands, you need to specify the name or ID of the custom image with the `IMAGE` variable.  To mark an image as deprecated, use the following command:  ```  ibmcloud is image-deprecate IMAGE  ``` - To mark an image as obsolete, use the following command:  ```  ibmcloud is image-obsolete IMAGE  ``` These commands allow you to make an immediate status change. Alternatively, you can schedule these status changes for a future date and time by using the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--deprecate-at` or `--obsolete-at` options. Finally, please note that you can only make an immediate status change if a future status change is not scheduled. If you have a scheduled status change, you need to remove it first.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Can I use the scheduling functionality to schedule a status change to obsolete in a month and to deprecated in two months?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Yes, as I described previously, you can use the scheduling functionality to schedule a status change to obsolete and deprecated in the future using the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--obsolete-at` and `--deprecate-at` options. Note, if you define both the deprecate-at and obsolete-at dates, the obsolete-at date must be after the deprecate-at date. In addition, when scheduling the date and time, you can't use your current date and time but a month and two months in the future is acceptable.

input.text: Thank you!

input.speaker: user
input.text: what makes the different shapes of the moon

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The different shapes of the Moon, also known as lunar phases, are determined by the amount of sunlight that is illuminating the portion of the Moon visible from Earth. This changes as the Moon orbits the Earth and the relative positions of the Moon, Earth, and Sun shift. When the Sun, Earth, and Moon are aligned, with the Sun and Moon on opposite sides of the Earth, we see a full moon. When the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun, we see a new moon. The crescent and gibbous shapes occur during the intervals between these principal phases, when only a portion of the Moon's surface is illuminated. The specific shape at any given time depends on the Moon's position in its orbit. When a sphere is illuminated on one hemisphere and viewed from a different angle , the portion of the illuminated area that is visible will have a two - dimensional shape defined by the intersection of an ellipse and circle ( where the major axis of the ellipse coincides with a diameter of the circle ) . If the half - ellipse is convex with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be gibbous ( bulging outwards ) whereas if the half - ellipse is concave with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be a crescent .

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the distance between the moon and earth?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The average distance from the Moon to the Earth is about 238,856 miles or 384,402 kilometers. But this distance varies throughout the Moon's orbit, ranging from about 221,500 miles or 385,000 kilometers at its closest, to about 252,700 miles or 406,700 kilometers at its farthest resulting in a differential range of 50,200 kilometers or 31,200 miles. Lunar distance (astronomy) Astronomers O'Keefe and Anderson calculated the lunar distance by observing 4 occultations from 9 locations in 1952 . They calculated a mean distance of 7008384407600000000 ♠ 384 407. 6 ± 4.7 km , however the value was refined by in 1962 by Irene Fischer , who incorporated updated geodetic data to produce a value of 7008384403700000000 ♠ 384 403. 7 ± 2 km .

input.speaker: user
input.text: How can I protect my personal information from identity theft

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
Here are some tips to protect your personal information from identity theft:
1. Do not respond to or click on any links within unsolicited emails or pop-up boxes. They can put your personal information in jeopardy.
2. Be cautious when using your debit card online. Consider using a credit card instead as they typically provide added protection against fraudulent charges.
3. Only download mobile applications from official app stores and check other users’ reviews, as well as the app’s privacy policies, before downloading.
4. Use a variety of strong and unique passwords for your online activities. Avoid using the same password for all your accounts.
5. Keep your financial documents and records in a secure place. Shred sensitive materials before disposing of them.
6. Secure your wireless network with a strong password and turn on Wireless Network Encryption if available.
7. Lock your computer when you are using it in a public or shared space.
8. Regularly update anti-virus protection software on your computer and keep your computer system and browser up to date.
9. Double-check mailings and always make sure that documents are not stuck together and that the recipient’s information is correct before sending any Personally Identifiable Information.
10. Avoid sending any sensitive information via email. If you must use email, consider purchasing encryption software.
11. Use social media responsibly and monitor your privacy settings.
12. Consider purchasing and using a reputable Virtual Private Network or VPN software to use while online using public networks.
For parents, it's important to start the conversation about online safety with your children, establish rules, monitor their playtime, and teach them about cell phone safety.

input.speaker: user
input.text: why was the eastern roman empire called the byzantine empire

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Modern historians refer to the Byzantine Empire as such to distinguish it from ancient Rome. This name comes from Byzantium, the original name of Constantinople, the capital city of the empire. The citizens of the empire continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire or Romania and to themselves as "Romans."

input.speaker: user
input.text: What was its religion?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
During the reign of Constantine in the Byzantine Empire, Christianity was not declared the exclusive state religion, but it received special favor from the emperor, who granted it generous privileges. Constantine also established the principle that emperors could not unilaterally decide matters of religious doctrine, and instead, they should convene general ecclesiastical councils for that purpose. His summoning of the Synod of Arles and the First Council of Nicaea demonstrated his commitment to the unity of the Church and asserted his authority as its leader.The ascendancy of Christianity was briefly challenged when Emperor Julian came to power in 361 and sought to revive polytheism throughout the empire. He was later known as "Julian the Apostate" by the Church. However, Julian's efforts were reversed when he died in battle in 363.
The foundation of the Byzantine Empire was based on the belief that it was a reflection of the Kingdom of Heaven on Earth. Just as God ruled in Heaven, the Emperor, created in His image, was expected to govern on Earth and uphold His commandments. The empire aspired to be universal and aimed to encompass all the peoples of the Earth. Ideally, all people would be members of the one true Christian Church, the Orthodox Church.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was reorganized?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Constantine I reorganized the Roman Empire in the early 4th century, around 324-337 AD. This reorganization included establishing Constantinople as the new capital and legalizing Christianity. Constantine's changes marked a significant shift that set the stage for the development of the Byzantine Empire as a distinct entity from the classical Roman Empire. Constantine moved the seat of the Empire to Constantinople, which he founded as a second Rome on the site of Byzantium, a city strategically located on the trade routes between Europe and Asia and between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Constantine significantly changed the Empire's military, monetary, civil, and religious institutions.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Why it fall?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: There are different theories about why Rome fell. One theory suggests that the victorious legions, who acquired the vices of strangers and mercenaries during distant wars, first oppressed the republic's freedom and later violated the majesty of the purple. Emperors, concerned for their personal safety and public peace, resorted to corrupting the military discipline, ultimately leading to the military government's weakening and dissolution. This weakening was further exacerbated by the partial institutions of Constantine, ultimately leading to the Roman world being overrun by Barbarians. Historians are still analyzing the reasons for the loss of political control over a vast territory and the survival of the Eastern Roman Empire. Alexander Demandt listed 210 theories on why Rome fell, and new ideas continue to emerge. Gibbon's classic formulation of reasons for the Fall sparked ongoing controversy about the role of Christianity but also emphasized other causes of internal decline and external attacks on the Empire.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was it found?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The Romans did not consistently use a specific system for numbering the years from the founding of their city. Different historians had different dates for the founding. Roman historians used the AUC system to measure the number of years between events rather than to indicate the date of a year. The Fasti Capitolini used an epoch of 752 BC, while modern historians have adopted the epoch of Varro, 753 BC. The AUC dating system was sometimes added in Renaissance manuscripts, giving the false impression that the Romans numbered their years. Censorinus stated that, in his time, the AUC year began with the Parilia, celebrated on 21 April, which was seen as the actual anniversary of the foundation of Rome. According to Roman myth, Rome was founded by Romulus, the first to dedicate spoils taken from an enemy ruler to the Temple of Jupiter Feretrius. In subsequent wars, blood-stained armor and weaponry were gathered and placed in temples as a symbol of respect towards the enemies' deities and as a way to win their patronage.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Stay within the boundaries of what is now known as Italy.

input.speaker: agent
input.text: No, it expanded. Rome began expanding shortly after the founding of the Republic in the 6th century BC, but it did not expand beyond the Italian Peninsula until the 3rd century BC. In the 8th century, the Franks, with the support of the Catholic Church, established an Empire that encompassed most of Western Europe. When Charlemagne (known as Karl der Große in German) inherited the Frankish realm, he expanded it to cover all of Central and Western Europe, except for the southern tip of Italy and Iberia. He proclaimed the reestablishment of the Roman Empire (calling it the Holy Roman Empire) and was crowned as Roman Emperor by the Pope in Rome.

input.text: 401(k) contributions are pre-tax dollars. A 401k account is taxed when you withdraw the money upon retirement. This is similar to how an IRA is taxed. The idea behind this is that you will likely be in a lower tax bracket at the time of retirement. It's important to note that 401k contributions reduce your taxable income for each paycheck, but they do not impact the level of your social security and medicare taxes. Also, the employer match is considered free money.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What do you mean by IRA?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: IRA stands for Individual Retirement Account. It's a type of retirement account where you can delay paying taxes now on your deposits or avoid paying taxes on your earnings later. You can set up a personal IRA for yourself, but not for employees. The investments within an IRA can vary - you can invest in certificates of deposit, stocks, bonds, mutual funds, or any mix of these. The taxation of an IRA is similar to a 401k, where contributions are made with pre-tax dollars and withdrawals are taxed upon retirement.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the different types of dialog nodes?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: There are various types of dialog nodes. These include the Welcome node, which greets users when interacting with the assistant, and the Anything else node, which provides responses for unrecognized user input. You can also create custom nodes by adding a condition that triggers the assistant to process the node. It is possible to create an intent that can be recognized when a customer asks to speak to someone. After defining the intent, you can add a root-level dialog node that conditions the intent.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Whatar are intents?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Intents are the purposes or goals expressed in a customer's input, such as answering a question or processing a bill payment. By recognizing the intent in a customer's input, the Watson Assistant service can choose the appropriate dialog flow to respond. Intents added from a content catalog are distinguishable from other intents by their names. Each intent name is prefixed with the content catalog name.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How is it created?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
To create a dialogue, follow these steps:
1. Click the Dialog tab and then click Create dialog. When you open the dialog editor for the first time, the Welcome and Anything else nodes will be created for you.
2. To add more nodes, click the "More" icon on the Welcome node and select Add node below.
3. In the "If assistant recognizes" field, enter a condition that, when met, triggers your assistant to process the node. Typically, you want to add an intent as the condition.
4. Specify the condition and response for each node. The condition specifies the information that must be present in the user input for the node to be triggered, while the response is the utterance that your assistant uses to respond to the user.
5. Save your progress.
Remember, the dialogue matches intents (what users say) to responses (what the bot says back) and can ask for more details in a text response and create one or more child nodes to process the new input.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
There are some potential advantages and disadvantages of Immutable Object Storage:  
Advantages:  
1. Data Integrity and Long-term Data Retention: Immutable Object Storage preserves electronic records and maintains data integrity. It ensures that data is stored in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many), no-erasable and non-rewritable manner, which can be beneficial for industries like Financial, Healthcare, and Media content archives where data integrity is crucial. 
 2. Compliance: Immutable Object Storage can help organizations comply with certain regulations like SEC Rule 17a-4(f), FINRA Rule 4511(c), and CFTC Rule 1.31(c)-(d) that govern electronic records storage and retention. When using immutable Object Storage, it is the client's responsibility to check for and ensure whether any of the feature capabilities that are discussed can be used to satisfy and comply with the key rules around electronic records storage and retention governed by the above-mentioned regulations.
Disadvantages:  
1. Limited Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only. Users outside these regions may not be able to use this feature. 
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan, which could be a disadvantage for users looking for more affordable options.  
3. No High-speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy. This could potentially slow down the data transfer process.  
4. Irreversible: Once permanent retention is enabled, it can't be reversed. Objects uploaded that use a permanent retention period cannot be deleted. This means users need to be sure about their need to permanently store objects. 
5. Legal Holds: The retention policy is enforced until the end of a retention period and the removal of any legal holds. This could potentially cause issues if there are legal disputes or investigations. Please note that the actual advantages and disadvantages may vary depending on the specific use case and requirements.
To assist clients in making informed decisions, IBM engaged Cohasset Associates Inc. to conduct an independent assessment of IBM’s Immutable Object Storage.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How long is the Wall?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The frontier walls built by different dynasties have multiple courses. Collectively, they stretch from Dandong in the east to Lop Lake in the west, from present - day Sino - Russian border in the north to Qinghai in the south. The walls built by the Ming dynasty measure 8,850 km. Faced with the threat of the Göktürks from the north, the Qi built up to 3,000 li about 1,600 kilometers. The Xuan - Da portion of the Great Wall totaled about 850 kilometers of wall, with some sections being doubled - up with two lines of wall, some tripled or even quadrupled. Chancellor Wanyan Xiang convinced the emperor to build an extensive systems of walls, which consisted of a 700 kilometers outer wall from Heilongjiang to Mongolia and a 1,000 kilometers network of inner walls, north and northeast of Beijing. Together, they formed a roughly elliptical web of fortifications 1,400 kilometers in length.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Who was the enemy?

input.text: Many scholars have operated under the belief that the Great Wall continually defended China 's border against the raids and invasions of the various nomadic groups of the Eurasian Steppe with an eye to expansion. Towards the end of the Ming, the Great Wall helped defend the empire against the Manchu invasions that began around 1600. The usefulness of the Great Wall as a defense line against northern nomads became questionable under the Qing dynasty, since China proper, Manchuria, and Mongolia were all under Qing control. So instead, the Great Wall became the means to limit Han Chinese movement into the steppes. Rather than being defensive, the walls indicate the northward expansions of the three northern states and their desire to safeguard their recent territorial acquisitions.

input.text: What is Qin Shi Huang known for?

input.text: In 221 BC , the state of Qin completed its conquest over the other Warring States and united China under Qin Shi Huang , the first emperor of China. Intending to impose centralized rule and prevent the resurgence of feudal lords , he ordered the destruction of the sections of the walls that divided his empire. Contrary to the building of the outer walls, which were built to stabilize the newly united China, the inner walls threatened the unity of the empire. In the north, the state of Wei and the Yiqu built walls to protect themselves from Qin aggression, but were still unable to stop Qin from eating into their territories. The settlement of the north continued up to Qin Shi Huang 's death in 210 BC.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What did Meng Tian do?

input.text: Meng Tian was a Chinese general and politician who served under Emperor Qin Shi Huang during the Qin Dynasty. He is best known for leading the northern expedition against the Xiongnu people. Meng Tian was responsible for building and extending the Great Wall of China along the empire's northern border. Meng Tian introduced 30,000 settler families to colonize the newly conquered territories. When Meng Tian's settlements in the north were abandoned, the Xiongnu nomads moved back into the Ordos Loop as the Qin empire became consumed by widespread rebellion. Upon Qin Shi Huang's death in 210 BC, Meng Tian was ordered to commit suicide in a succession conspiracy.

Five years later, the renovated Badaling became the first section to be opened to the public since the establishment of the PRC. The Badaling Great Wall has since become a staple stop for foreign dignitaries.

input.text: The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) is a United States federal law that defines and protects the institution of marriage. enacted in 1996. It was introduced by Georgia Representative Bob Barr and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma. The Act was intended by Congress to reflect and honor a collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality. It also defined marriage for federal purposes as the legal union of a man and a woman as husband and wife, and a spouse as a husband or wife of the opposite sex. Section 3 of DOMA defines marriage and spouse for federal purposes. Section 3 codified non-recognition of same - sex marriages for all federal purposes, including insurance benefits for government employees, social security survivors ' benefits, immigration, bankruptcy, and the filing of joint tax returns, as well as excluding same - sex spouses from the scope of laws protecting families of federal officers, laws evaluating financial aid eligibility, and federal ethics laws applicable to opposite - sex spouses.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How are weddings celebrated?

input.text: The typical wedding involves a couple proclaiming their commitment to one another in front of their close relatives and friends , often presided over by a religious figure such as a minister , priest , or rabbi , depending upon the faith of the couple . In traditional Christian ceremonies , the bride 's father will `` give away '' ( hand off ) the bride to the groom . Secular weddings are also common , often presided over by a judge , Justice of the Peace , or other municipal official . At a wedding reception , the father of the bride , in his role as host , regularly offers the first toast , thanking the guests for attending , offering tasteful remembrances of the bride 's childhood , and wishing the newlyweds a happy life together . The best man usually proposes a toast in the form of best wishes and congratulations to the newlyweds . A best man 's toast takes the form of a short speech ( 3 -- 5 minutes ) that combines a mixture of humor and sincerity . The actual `` toast '' is then delivered at the end of the speech and is a short phrase wishing the newlyweds a happy , healthy , loving life together . The maid of honor may follow suit , appropriately tailoring her comments to the bride . The groom may offer the final toast , thanking the bride 's parents for hosting the wedding , the wedding party for their participation , and finally dedicating the toast to the bridesmaids .

On the other hand, bad bots range from malicious to simply annoying; for instance, breaking into user accounts to steal data or buying concert tickets online to assist scalpers. Malicious bots typically don't  check a website's robots.txt file before accessing the website, which generates the need for bot management.

This detection technique gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS and cannot identify specific individuals. Additional steps are taken to anonymize and phase out data for privacy.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Assuming the question is about the IBM Cloud® Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI),  version 6.15.0 includes the following changes over version 6.14.0. It introduces new commands image-obsolete and image-deprecate for image lifecycle management. It also adds support for image lifecycle management in image-create, image-update, and images commands and it fixes an issue with using the SSH key generated from UI in CLI.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Tell me more about the new commands

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The new commands introduced in version 6.15.0 of the IBM Cloud® Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI) are image-obsolete and image-deprecate. These commands support image lifecycle management, allowing users to manage the lifecycle of their custom images more effectively. The image-obsolete command can be used to mark an image as obsolete, indicating that it is no longer available to be used to provision an instance. The image-deprecate command can be used to mark an image as deprecated, discouraging its use before it becomes obsolete.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How do I use them?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: To use the new `image-obsolete` and `image-deprecate` commands, you need to specify the name or ID of the custom image with the `IMAGE` variable.  To mark an image as deprecated, use the following command:  ```  ibmcloud is image-deprecate IMAGE  ``` - To mark an image as obsolete, use the following command:  ```  ibmcloud is image-obsolete IMAGE  ``` These commands allow you to make an immediate status change. Alternatively, you can schedule these status changes for a future date and time by using the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--deprecate-at` or `--obsolete-at` options. Finally, please note that you can only make an immediate status change if a future status change is not scheduled. If you have a scheduled status change, you need to remove it first.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Can I use the scheduling functionality to schedule a status change to obsolete in a month and to deprecated in two months?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Yes, as I described previously, you can use the scheduling functionality to schedule a status change to obsolete and deprecated in the future using the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--obsolete-at` and `--deprecate-at` options. Note, if you define both the deprecate-at and obsolete-at dates, the obsolete-at date must be after the deprecate-at date. In addition, when scheduling the date and time, you can't use your current date and time but a month and two months in the future is acceptable.

input.speaker: user
input.text: what makes the different shapes of the moon

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The different shapes of the Moon, also known as lunar phases, are determined by the amount of sunlight that is illuminating the portion of the Moon visible from Earth. This changes as the Moon orbits the Earth and the relative positions of the Moon, Earth, and Sun shift. When the Sun, Earth, and Moon are aligned, with the Sun and Moon on opposite sides of the Earth, we see a full moon. When the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun, we see a new moon. The crescent and gibbous shapes occur during the intervals between these principal phases, when only a portion of the Moon's surface is illuminated. The specific shape at any given time depends on the Moon's position in its orbit. When a sphere is illuminated on one hemisphere and viewed from a different angle , the portion of the illuminated area that is visible will have a two - dimensional shape defined by the intersection of an ellipse and circle ( where the major axis of the ellipse coincides with a diameter of the circle ) . If the half - ellipse is convex with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be gibbous ( bulging outwards ) whereas if the half - ellipse is concave with respect to the half - circle , then the shape will be a crescent .

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the distance between the moon and earth?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The average distance from the Moon to the Earth is about 238,856 miles or 384,402 kilometers. But this distance varies throughout the Moon's orbit, ranging from about 221,500 miles or 385,000 kilometers at its closest, to about 252,700 miles or 406,700 kilometers at its farthest resulting in a differential range of 50,200 kilometers or 31,200 miles. Lunar distance (astronomy) Astronomers O'Keefe and Anderson calculated the lunar distance by observing 4 occultations from 9 locations in 1952 . They calculated a mean distance of 7008384407600000000 ♠ 384 407. 6 ± 4.7 km , however the value was refined by in 1962 by Irene Fischer , who incorporated updated geodetic data to produce a value of 7008384403700000000 ♠ 384 403. 7 ± 2 km .

input.speaker: user
input.text: How can I protect my personal information from identity theft

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
Here are some tips to protect your personal information from identity theft:
1. Do not respond to or click on any links within unsolicited emails or pop-up boxes. They can put your personal information in jeopardy.
2. Be cautious when using your debit card online. Consider using a credit card instead as they typically provide added protection against fraudulent charges.
3. Only download mobile applications from official app stores and check other users’ reviews, as well as the app’s privacy policies, before downloading.
4. Use a variety of strong and unique passwords for your online activities. Avoid using the same password for all your accounts.
5. Keep your financial documents and records in a secure place. Shred sensitive materials before disposing of them.
6. Secure your wireless network with a strong password and turn on Wireless Network Encryption if available.
7. Lock your computer when you are using it in a public or shared space.
8. Regularly update anti-virus protection software on your computer and keep your computer system and browser up to date.
9. Double-check mailings and always make sure that documents are not stuck together and that the recipient’s information is correct before sending any Personally Identifiable Information.
10. Avoid sending any sensitive information via email. If you must use email, consider purchasing encryption software.
11. Use social media responsibly and monitor your privacy settings.
12. Consider purchasing and using a reputable Virtual Private Network or VPN software to use while online using public networks.
For parents, it's important to start the conversation about online safety with your children, establish rules, monitor their playtime, and teach them about cell phone safety.

input.text: why was the eastern roman empire called the byzantine empire

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Modern historians refer to the Byzantine Empire as such to distinguish it from ancient Rome. This name comes from Byzantium, the original name of Constantinople, the capital city of the empire. The citizens of the empire continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire or Romania and to themselves as "Romans."

input.speaker: user
input.text: What was its religion?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
During the reign of Constantine in the Byzantine Empire, Christianity was not declared the exclusive state religion, but it received special favor from the emperor, who granted it generous privileges. Constantine also established the principle that emperors could not unilaterally decide matters of religious doctrine, and instead, they should convene general ecclesiastical councils for that purpose. His summoning of the Synod of Arles and the First Council of Nicaea demonstrated his commitment to the unity of the Church and asserted his authority as its leader.The ascendancy of Christianity was briefly challenged when Emperor Julian came to power in 361 and sought to revive polytheism throughout the empire. He was later known as "Julian the Apostate" by the Church. However, Julian's efforts were reversed when he died in battle in 363.
The foundation of the Byzantine Empire was based on the belief that it was a reflection of the Kingdom of Heaven on Earth. Just as God ruled in Heaven, the Emperor, created in His image, was expected to govern on Earth and uphold His commandments. The empire aspired to be universal and aimed to encompass all the peoples of the Earth. Ideally, all people would be members of the one true Christian Church, the Orthodox Church.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was reorganized?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: Constantine I reorganized the Roman Empire in the early 4th century, around 324-337 AD. This reorganization included establishing Constantinople as the new capital and legalizing Christianity. Constantine's changes marked a significant shift that set the stage for the development of the Byzantine Empire as a distinct entity from the classical Roman Empire. Constantine moved the seat of the Empire to Constantinople, which he founded as a second Rome on the site of Byzantium, a city strategically located on the trade routes between Europe and Asia and between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Constantine significantly changed the Empire's military, monetary, civil, and religious institutions.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Why it fall?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: There are different theories about why Rome fell. One theory suggests that the victorious legions, who acquired the vices of strangers and mercenaries during distant wars, first oppressed the republic's freedom and later violated the majesty of the purple. Emperors, concerned for their personal safety and public peace, resorted to corrupting the military discipline, ultimately leading to the military government's weakening and dissolution. This weakening was further exacerbated by the partial institutions of Constantine, ultimately leading to the Roman world being overrun by Barbarians. Historians are still analyzing the reasons for the loss of political control over a vast territory and the survival of the Eastern Roman Empire. Alexander Demandt listed 210 theories on why Rome fell, and new ideas continue to emerge. Gibbon's classic formulation of reasons for the Fall sparked ongoing controversy about the role of Christianity but also emphasized other causes of internal decline and external attacks on the Empire.

input.speaker: user
input.text: When was it found?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The Romans did not consistently use a specific system for numbering the years from the founding of their city. Different historians had different dates for the founding. Roman historians used the AUC system to measure the number of years between events rather than to indicate the date of a year. The Fasti Capitolini used an epoch of 752 BC, while modern historians have adopted the epoch of Varro, 753 BC. The AUC dating system was sometimes added in Renaissance manuscripts, giving the false impression that the Romans numbered their years. Censorinus stated that, in his time, the AUC year began with the Parilia, celebrated on 21 April, which was seen as the actual anniversary of the foundation of Rome. According to Roman myth, Rome was founded by Romulus, the first to dedicate spoils taken from an enemy ruler to the Temple of Jupiter Feretrius. In subsequent wars, blood-stained armor and weaponry were gathered and placed in temples as a symbol of respect towards the enemies' deities and as a way to win their patronage.

When Charlemagne (known as Karl der Große in German) inherited the Frankish realm, he expanded it to cover all of Central and Western Europe, except for the southern tip of Italy and Iberia. He proclaimed the reestablishment of the Roman Empire (calling it the Holy Roman Empire) and was crowned as Roman Emperor by the Pope in Rome.

4. Specify the condition and response for each node. The condition specifies the information that must be present in the user input for the node to be triggered, while the response is the utterance that your assistant uses to respond to the user.
5. Save your progress.
Remember, the dialogue matches intents (what users say) to responses (what the bot says back) and can ask for more details in a text response and create one or more child nodes to process the new input.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?

input.speaker: agent
input.text:
There are some potential advantages and disadvantages of Immutable Object Storage:  
Advantages:  
1. Data Integrity and Long-term Data Retention: Immutable Object Storage preserves electronic records and maintains data integrity. It ensures that data is stored in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many), no-erasable and non-rewritable manner, which can be beneficial for industries like Financial, Healthcare, and Media content archives where data integrity is crucial. 
 2. Compliance: Immutable Object Storage can help organizations comply with certain regulations like SEC Rule 17a-4(f), FINRA Rule 4511(c), and CFTC Rule 1.31(c)-(d) that govern electronic records storage and retention. When using immutable Object Storage, it is the client's responsibility to check for and ensure whether any of the feature capabilities that are discussed can be used to satisfy and comply with the key rules around electronic records storage and retention governed by the above-mentioned regulations.
Disadvantages:  
1. Limited Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only. Users outside these regions may not be able to use this feature. 
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan, which could be a disadvantage for users looking for more affordable options.  
3. No High-speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy. This could potentially slow down the data transfer process.  
4. Irreversible: Once permanent retention is enabled, it can't be reversed. Objects uploaded that use a permanent retention period cannot be deleted. This means users need to be sure about their need to permanently store objects. 
5. Legal Holds: The retention policy is enforced until the end of a retention period and the removal of any legal holds. This could potentially cause issues if there are legal disputes or investigations. Please note that the actual advantages and disadvantages may vary depending on the specific use case and requirements.
To assist clients in making informed decisions, IBM engaged Cohasset Associates Inc. to conduct an independent assessment of IBM’s Immutable Object Storage.

input.text: what is the great wall of China built out of

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The Great Wall of China was built using various materials over different periods. Originally, it was mainly constructed from rammed earth, stones, and wood. During the Ming Dynasty (1368--1644), bricks became heavily used, along with materials such as tiles, lime, and stone. The bricks were easier to work with, could bear more weight, and endured better than rammed earth.

input.speaker: user
input.text: How long is the Wall?

input.speaker: agent
input.text: The frontier walls built by different dynasties have multiple courses. Collectively, they stretch from Dandong in the east to Lop Lake in the west, from present - day Sino - Russian border in the north to Qinghai in the south. The walls built by the Ming dynasty measure 8,850 km. Faced with the threat of the Göktürks from the north, the Qi built up to 3,000 li about 1,600 kilometers. The Xuan - Da portion of the Great Wall totaled about 850 kilometers of wall, with some sections being doubled - up with two lines of wall, some tripled or even quadrupled. Chancellor Wanyan Xiang convinced the emperor to build an extensive systems of walls, which consisted of a 700 kilometers outer wall from Heilongjiang to Mongolia and a 1,000 kilometers network of inner walls, north and northeast of Beijing. Together, they formed a roughly elliptical web of fortifications 1,400 kilometers in length.
